variant.title: Example-Based Sense Tagging of Running Chinese Text
variant.author: Xiang Tong Chang-ning Huang Cheng-ming Gun
variant.bodyText: This paper describes a sense tagging technique for the auto- matic sense tagging of running Chinese text. The system takes as input running Chinese text, and outputs sense disambiguated text. Whereas previous work (Yarowsity, 1992; Gale, et al. , 1992, 1993) relies heavily on the role of statistics, the present system makes use of Machine Readable/Tractable Dictionaries (Wilks, et al. , 1990; Guo, in press) and an example-based rea- soning technique (Naga°, 1984; Sumita, et al. , 1990) to treat novel words, compound words, and phrases found in the input text.

If the 1980's were characterized by the surge of efforts on Machine Read- able/Tractable Dictionary (MRD/MTD) research, the 1990's would be a time of massive efforts on constructing annotated text corpora. Properly annotated text corpora could form, at least, the bases for the following: a. the core of commercial information systems; b. the kernel engine of 'Cognitive Agents'; c. the essentials of systems vital to national security. Sense tagging of large text corpora has been on the back-burner for too

long. The preparation of large annotated text corpora, especially those with word sense disambiguated, has always been brushed aside for some piteous 'smart' approaches to prevail. However, it is just this kind of hopeless clever- ness that handicapped the speedy growth of the language enterprise. Fortunate- ly, more and more researchers have come to realize the importance, as well as the necessity, of being earnest in annotating large text corpora of all major lan- guages. The present discussion presents a system for the automatic sense tagging of running Chinese text — — a necessary mechanism for the construction of anno- tated 'Monitor Corpora' (Sinclare, 1991) that do not degrade over time. The system takes as input running Chinese text, and outputs sense disambiguated text. Whereas previous work (farowsky, 1992; Gale, et al. , 1992, 1993) re- lies heavily on the role of statistics, the present system makes use of Machine Readable/Tractable Dictionaries (Wilks, et al. , 1990; Guo, in press) and an example-based reasoning technique (Nagao, 1984; Sumita, et al. , 1990) to treat novel words, compound words, and phrases found in the input text. The focus of this discussion is on the example-based reasoning technique. The exam- ples that support the tagging operation come from the system MTD. The sense tagging system assigns a unique number for every Chinese charac- ters occurred in the text. In most cases, the senses tagged are word senses. This is due to the fact that most Chinese characters are words. For example, `f7' ( beat) has 26 senses. (drum) has 6 senses. The phrase 'rill, (beat drums) becomes `rf_B02 i-A01' after sense tagging. However, not all Chi- nese characters are words. Sometimes they are bound morphemes. In these cas- es, the senses tagged are the meanings of the morphemes as given in the dictio- nary. For example, .pg- as in 'Ff' is tagged `A01' , which is the number of 'Far as given in the MTD when lap is used as a prefix, i. e. . a bound morpheme.

The sense-tagger under discussion represents partial results of some three years of continued efforts on the part of Tsinghua University, Beijing. China to build systems for the processing of general, unrestricted running Chinese texts. The system was implemented in 'C' and currently runs on the Sun Workstation at the National Al Laboratory in the University.
The sense-tagging module uses two MRDs and one MTD. The first MRD,

for the sake of discussion, say MRD-1,is (Fu. 1987). It contains about 6,000 one-syllable words, e. g. (beat), 'Pr (drum), and 43.000 compound words and phrases, e.g. '11,t' (beating drums). Each word has one or more word senses. For example, 'IT' (beat) has 26 senses and (drum) 6. Note that capital letters in the numbers tagged indicate homo- graphs, and the Arabic numbers the sense number under the homograph. The content of the word 'IT' (beat) is given as following:
variant.table: 17_ Bol: )›k* n--B02: 1T-B03: it# 1T_B04: 7-r-;A-1*.±.1Y1AllttiV 1-T_Bo5: Ep 1T_B06: 11-1313: ttot 1T-B08: 11-B15: TiczAf5.t tg, t3T tT-B17: tui 17-B12: fezAtiii:_eilai 11-B19: illatUz(1,144) fli5t IT-B21: rj-B16; 11-B23: -f-B18: 11-B25: fT-B20: nt+ tT-B22: 1T-1324: *,
variant.bodyText: The second MRD. for the sake of discussion, say MRD_ 2, is the Chinese thesaurus `E..zirW14.' (Mei, 1983) with about 70,000 entries. It has a 3-1ev- el categorization system. At Level 1, the dictionary has 12 major categories. At Level 2, the 12 major categories split into 94 subcategories. At the lowest level, Level 3. the dictionary has altogether 1,428 subcategories. Under the current numbering system, the capital letter indicates major categories, the lower-case letter subcategories, and the Arabic numbers the numbering under the two su- perordinate categories. For example, `13p13' refers to one of the categories that the word `tt.' (drum) falls into. B is a first level category, p is a second level subcategory, 13 is the numbering of the subcategory under Bp. Partial list of the numbering of some\categories is given as follows:
variant.equation: Bp13 Fa01 Fa30 Ic05 Hc26 Be04 Bho5 hi Bh07 E Fa23 Hd16 Dm05 Bp13 trff Bp10 4,7 1d03 1e14
variant.bodyText: The MTD was constructed from MRD- 1. It has 43,000 annotated com- pound words and phrases. Word phrases like 'ITW (beating drums) are disam- biguated in the MTD with word sense numbers tagged to both 'IT' (beat) arid '11A' (drum). e.g. `1-T_B02 A01' . The numbers tagged are based on the numbering system as used in MRD_1. For those compounds that have compo- nent whose meaning is not related to the resultant compound, the Arabic num- bers in the component's tag is '00' (e. g. , _A00 A01, 114-_ A00 A00). Much of the work in constructing the MTD was done by machine, but supplemented by handcoding. The following gives a partial list of the con- tents of the MTD :
variant.equation: IT-B01 01_ A03 fl_B01 tg_Boi mBoi rr_1302 t_A02 1r-B02 -A0 r-B02 A01 Tr_B03 1,13_A01 rf_B03 fT_B05 t_A02
variant.bodyText: Step 1 : Segmenting the input text into words, compound words and phrases The word segmentation module is a much simplied version of a more compli- cated segmentation program developed at the Laboratory. It looks forward through each sentence for maximum match of character strings as recorded in the MTD. The tagging of most known phrases is done with the help of the MTD. 'Mr would be an example in question. The involved operation is simple, i. e. 'match to access'. When an input segment matches an entry in the MTD, the tagged form of the matched segment replaces the input segment in the sentence.
variant.subsubsectionHeader: Step 2: Example-based sense tagging of one-syllable words
variant.bodyText: The system uses an example-based sense-tagging algorithm for the disam- biguation of one-syllable words, which are not listed in system MTD. The detail of the algorithm is described in Section 3. Step 3 : Default sense tagging of untaggea' one-syllable words from Step 2 A default sense number is assigned to each and every one syllable word un- tagged from Step 2. The default sense numbers are determined on the basis of frequency of occurrence data.

Chinese words build to form compound words. In 94. 7% of the time, the meaning of the resultant compounds is related to the contributing meanings of the component words (Zhang, 1986, p. 87). The compound words and phrases in the MTD contain implicit syntactic information for purpose of example-based rea- soning about the senses of Chinese words in context. For example, if 4n- ga, (beat gongs and drums ) is in the input text and the sense of 'n" (beat) cannot be determined. In order to disambiguate the word sense of 'IP (beat), the system looks through the MTD for every com- pound word and phrase beginning with ,n, (beat) and decides that the phrases IT_ B02 a_A01' (beat drums) is an appropriate example to reason about the word ' (beat) as found in `1" OITA' (beat gongs and drums). since 1A' (drums) and `53 a, (gongs and drums) are in the same lowest category `13p13' in MRD_ 2. The system then assigns the tag B02' . which belongs to IT' (beat) in `1"_B02 _A01' (beat drums), to 'Iv (beat) in (beat gongs and drums). Formally, when S, S2••• S„ represent input segments from 1 to n, W repre- sents an untagged segment, and the immediate context of W is represented by L2 L1 W R R2--• where L stands for 'Left' , R stands for 'Right' and range equals 5, we have the following: Si S2 "• S„ (a) where Sk(k=1, --• n) is a word, compound word or phrase

where Li, Ri(i=1, ,range) is a word, compound word or phrase In the forward reasoning process, assuming that (W R,) is a possible com- pound word or phrase, for all entries in MTD beginning with W which is in the form (W_ tag Item), the system computes the relatedness of the two words or phrases (W R,) and (W_tag Item), where 'Item' may be an annotated word, compound word, phrase, or just a meaningless Chinese character string. The concept distance of R, arid Item is computed to determine the relatedness of the two compound words/phrases. Hence.
variant.table: Concept-Distance(R,, Item) = 0 if R, and Item are in the same lowest category in MRD_2 1 if R, and Item are in the adjacent categories in MRD_2 100 all other cases Relatedness( (147 (W_tag Item)) =
variant.equation: 2 if Concept_ Distance (R, , Item) = 0 1 if Concept_ Distance (R,, Item) = 1 0 if Concept_Distance(R,, Item) = 100
variant.bodyText: For every pair of (W R,) (i=1, ••• 'range) and (W_ tag Item) in the MTD, the pair that has the greatest non-zero relatedness measure is determined and the W in (b) above is substituted by the W_tag in the determined pair. The reasoning process works similarly in both directions of W i. e. for- ward to R,,„ and backward to When the process proceeds forward, the system looks for entries beginning with W. On the other hand, when the process works backwards to the left of W, the system looks for annotated entries in the MTD ending with W. The examples are given as following:

The word 4g-r, (new) has six senses. The annotated phrase lw_ACI1 A01 is found in the MTD. The system calculates the conceptual distance be- tween '1' and .aft' among others. Since and ',Tuft' are found to be in the same lowest subcategory `Dd061. the conceptual distance between them is 0. The system then assigns the tag A01' , which belongs to ‘g, as in 'ffi- A01 .A0]',M to in the above sentence.

The word 'It' (receive, suffer) has six senses. The annotated phrase `1:-/102 V"-A02' is found in the MTD. The system calculates the conceptual distance between and 'Igf' among others. Since `W' and '104' are found to he in the adjacent lowest subcategories, i. e. 'fic18" and 'Hc19' re- spectively, the conceptual distance between them is 1. The system then assigns the tag 'A02' , which belongs to 't' as in '..f._A02 W_A02'1 to in the above sentence.

The word '4Z (right, power) has seven senses. The annotated phrase 14._A01 V_AOl' is found in the MTD. The system calculates the conceptual distance between It' and 41' among others. Since elffit' and TA.7'=' are found to be in the same lowest subcategory 4Dj03' , the conceptual distance be-

tween them is 0. The system then assigns the tag 'AO1' which belongs to IR' as in V-A01 , to 1' in the above sentence. The word 'tfl' (each other) has four senses. The annotated phrase '*- A01 VF_ A01' is found in the MTD. The system calculates the conceptual dis- tance between Tr and '1111,' among others. Since 'ft' and '2)11' are found to be in the same lowest subcategory `Jc01' , the conceptual distance between them is 0. The system then assigns the tag `A01' . which belongs to as in '_A01 _A01' , to 'tl]' in the above sentence.

The input Chinese texts that the present system works on are news release texts from the official Chinese Xinhua News Agency. No preprocessing of these news release texts is required. The performance of the present sense-tagger is encouraging. The hit rate of correct sense tagging can run as high as 95%. The lowest hit rate ever recorded was 70%. The appendix gives a sample text which is the output of our system. The hit rate of correct sense tagging of this sample is 93.79%. Essentially, the hit rate of correct sense tagging performed by the system is a function of the cov- erage of the system MTD and MRDs.

a. The system makes errors when the segmentation of the input texts is less than correct. The performance of the current sense tagger can be improved if more sophisticated segmentation method is adopted. b. Although the reasoning process takes advantage of collocational informa- tion within the phrase in which the untagged segment is a part. there is no guar- antee that the phrase does not have multiple meanings. When such cases occur, the result of the reasoning is subject to chance. c. The example-based sense tagging method works quite well with content words, but for function words it often makes faulty guesses. This is partly due to the fact that function words are less sensitive to context. The current system assigns a default sense number for most function words. However, for those words which can both be a function word and a content word, the system often makes errors. This kind of errors decreases when the system preprocesses the in- put texts with a stochastic Chinese grammatical tagger like the one developed at Tsinghua University (Bai, et at. 1992).

In this paper we presented a relatively simple but effective method for the sense tagging of running Chinese texts. The system takes advantage of the collo- cation information within the annotated compound words or phrases in the sys- tern MTD. Considering that annotated Chinese texts constitute very useful re- sources for Chinese language processing, especially in generating frequency of oc- currence/co-occurrence data, general and special purpose concordances and the data for the derivation of a natural set of semantic primitive for the Chinese lan- guage, the current sense-tagging system looks promising. The room for progress is to be found in the further improvement of the system resources and the refine- ment of the reasoning algorithm.

Bai, S-H, Xia, Y. , Huang, C-L. (1992) Research on Chinese grammatical tagging method for Chinese corpus. In: Chen, Z-X (Ed.). Development in machine translation. W.. and Yarowsky, D. (1993) A method fordis- ambiguating word senses in a large corpus. To appear in: Computers and Humanities. (1984) A framework of a mechanical translation between Japanese and English by analogy example. In: A. Elithorn, R. Benerji, (Eds), Ar- tificial and Human Intelligence. Elsevier: Amsterdam. Sumita, E. , lida. H. and Kohyama, H. (1990) Translating with examples: a newapproach to machine translation. (1992) Word-sense disambiguation using statistical models of Roget's categories trained on large corpora. COLING-92 Zhang , W. (1986) Character Meanings and Word Meanings. variant.title: Example-Based Sense Tagging of Running Chinese Text Xiang Tong Chang-ning
variant.author: Cheng-ming Gun
variant.abstract: This paper describes a sense tagging technique for the automatic sense tagging of running Chinese text. The system takes as input running Chinese text, and outputs sense disambiguated text. Whereas previous work (Yarowsity, 1992; Gale, et al. , 1992, 1993) relies heavily on the role of statistics, the present system makes use of Machine Readable/Tractable Dictionaries (Wilks, et al. , 1990; Guo, in press) and an example-based reasoning technique (Naga°, 1984; Sumita, et al. , 1990) to treat novel words, compound words, and phrases found in the input text.
